messageBody:
Hi Frank,

Regarding your comment on :
* Some guys say JUnit is good for biz / util code testing. But for web
application development, where HTML/javascript would be root cause of lots
of bugs, Junit is not so powerful. Any comments ?

I've used the following at one point or another, and they are all pretty
decent:

http://jwebunit.sourceforge.net/
Or
http://webtest.canoo.com/webtest/manual/WebTestHome.html

Which are both based on

http://httpunit.sourceforge.net/
And
http://htmlunit.sourceforge.net/
Respectively.

An automated Webtesting is essential for regression testing releases. Unless
you can afford to pay a group of testers to check the same tasks every time
you release a piece of software.

In enterprise applications, you'll save man months with an automated
Web-based Unit test regression test.

This page lists quite a few options for testing software:

http://www.softwareqatest.com/qatweb1.html

Finally, (and possibly a little OT) to add to this thread, I'd be very
interested in anyone's opinion on these though (Hope you don't mind this
hijack Frank but I think its relevant!) these are the Click your way through
a series of web pages to perform "something" and it will be repeated for you
by software, good for an End to End approach to testing.

Not sure if it can still be classed as Unit testing though, so apologies in
advance if this is OT.

http://www.crimsonsolutions.co.uk/testing/testing-downloads.php
http://www.pushtotest.com/Downloads/features.html

Again, apologies if this is OT, and J.B. thanks for the JUnit Recipes book
:)
Cheers,
Oisin

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
frank zou
Sent: 09 February 2006 13:41
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial
software development ?


Hi all,

After lots of reading and trying, I think I understand the following
benefits that Junit-base testing can give us:

* more robust system
* clean / good design
* less regression bugs
* confidence to do refactorying, especially at the later phase of the
project.
* and lots more...

These are really good things, for open-source projects where there is no
deadline pressure and resource could almost be thought as un-limitted.
However, for commercial software development, is this still possible ?


Although I knew JUnit and other JUnit-based open-source tools for a couple
of years, my company and team never really enbrace it. The major reason is
Product Managers always want to add cool features to the system quickly
while programmers find the schedule is always too tight to spend any extra
time to write testing.

I know from the mail list and books that we can take lots of advantage of
JUnit-based testing, I myself have no real hands-on experience on it. So
here are my questions:

* Will Junit-based testing make the project time longer or shorter ?
Any hard statistic data ? ( Here I mean commercial project rather than
open-source project. )

* One intersting point I found is that after Junit-based testing is
introduced, programmers tend to use IDE debugger much less than before.
This would save lots of time. Is that true ?

* Some guys say JUnit is good for biz / util code testing. But for web
application development, where HTML/javascript would be root cause of lots
of bugs, Junit is not so powerful. Any comments ?

* How can I convince managers and programmers that JUnit-based is really
possible for commercial software development ? Any differnece from
open-source projects ?



Can some Junit gurus shed some light here ?

Thanks,
- Frank
